Jan 18

Obama’s Propaganda Closely Resembled that of a Totalitarian Regime

I am not really into politics. I am well informed though. I read a couple of national and international newspapers and some magazines for more in depth information. I hardly ever feel compelled to comment on world events.

So for a few days now, I have been wondering and examining within myself a nagging feeling, exactly what it is that I find so disturbing about a recent newspaper article. It is something that has not, as far as I am aware, been picked up internationally much. If at all.

The article in question is a photo collection. In it a photo editor of De Volkskrant, a leading Dutch newspaper, puts side by side pictures of Obama and the North Korean boy-leader Kim Jong-un.

When I look at these pictures I am not so interested in the question of who is imitating who. Obama could be taking his cues from the propaganda of a totalitarian regime or it could be the other way around. Does that mean that America is suddenly a totalitarian regime? Of course not.

But the fact that the pictures are so thematically as well as compositionally similar, does make one wonder: if a ‘cult of personality’ is the hallmark of an totalitarian regime then what does it signify about a democratic regime if it employs the same methods?

I have always wondered, lacking a real yardstick by which to measure the veracity of what I read and see, how much of what I come across in the media is true. I have always suspected that perhaps 70 to 80 percent of what I read is true. That percentage may seem high to some, and it may seem low to others. But it is how I’ve always seen things. And for me, I am distrustful enough of the mainstream media that I usually do not comment on things. Precisely because I am always aware that I may not see the whole picture or be aware of all the facts.

But it is this kind of thing that makes me distrustful of the media as a whole. And I am sure I am not the only one this is happening to. Fake news and stories about russian armies of propagandists influencing the political opinions of western citizens is unavoidable nowadays.

Is it hyperbole to say: You just don’t know which news source to trust anymore? In effect he question becomes: who benefits? Who benefits from a wholesale distrust of the media? Who benefits from doubt?

Well, the answer to that question is quite obviously: those in power. For when you let people grow fat on a steady diet of lies and confusion, they are much less likely to unite and rise up against you.

Within the context of a totalitarian regime, the manifest goal is to control the availability of information, and to suppress dissent. It is important that the citizenry does not doubt the validity of your regime. Within the context of a modern connected democracy, the way to remain in power, is the opposite. If we cannot limit the amount of information or literally suppress dissent, perhaps we can cast doubt upon its detractors or crowd out their voices. If you can get people to a place where they say: I don’t know what is true anymore — and we are at that stage - you have effectively won. It is important to realize that this practice did not just start with Trump.

Politico writes:

“The mainstream media have always liked to believe that Obama isn’t the sort to manipulate the press, a sentiment he put in play when he arrived on the national political scene with his 2004 Democratic National Convention keynote address.”

Reading back that 2004 address I find this sentence:

“Now even as we speak, there are those who are preparing to divide us, the spin masters and negative ad peddlers who embrace the politics of anything goes.”

But it is quite clear, now, in hindsight, that ‘spin’ has been a major part of his strategy. Did you know that Obama’s main communication strategist did not have a degree in International Affairs or Law, but in, wait for it: Creative Writing.

One might well say it’s all water under the bridge now. Obama is done. But I guess what got me in the end is dissappointment. Disappointment not only in the change that obama’s administration could effect, but also, finally, disappointment in the change that he purported to represent.

So now there’s Trump. And what can we say about him? At least no one harbors any illusions concerning his honesty and trustworthiness. And that’s a good thing. With that I side with the channelers of Abraham as well as Edward Snowden. That perhaps people will stop hoping and expecting that their leaders are going to make it better for them. That we no longer trust what we see outside, and learn to trust more on what is inside.

And that, my friends, is progress.
